sen.j: 上杉 清子（うえすぎ きよこ、生年不詳 - 興国3年・康永元年12月23日 (旧暦)（1343年1月20日））は、鎌倉時代後期から室町時代初期の女性。
sen.e: Kiyoko UESUGI (date of birth unknown - January 20, 1343) was a woman who lived during the period of the later half of Kamakura Period through the early Muromachi Period.
Kiyoko UESUGI (date of birth unknown - January 20, 1343) was a woman who lived during the period of the later half of Kamakura Period through the early Muromachi Period.
Kiyoko UESUGI (date of birth unknown - January 20, 1343) was a woman who lived during the period of the later half of Kamakura Period through the early Muromachi Period.
Her maiden name was Fujiwara.
Her maiden name was Fujiwara.
Her maiden name was Fujiwara.

sen.j: 勧修寺流の一流である上杉氏の出身で、父は上杉頼重。
sen.e: She was from one of the schools of Kanjouji-ryu Temple and her Father was Yorishige UESUGI.

She was from one of the branch lines of Kaju-ji Temple line (one of the 13 families designated as "meike" (one of the court noble family ranks designated to assume a certain official post in government) branched out from the Takafuji line of the Northern House of Fujiwara clan); her Father was Yorishige UESUGI.
sen.cmt: 「勧修寺」の読みは「かじゅうじ」のほうが適切であると判断し、そのように修正しました。ここでの一流は流派のうちでも「家」を指し、特に「勧修寺流」は「名家」の「家格」に叙せられた一流家格の流れを指すため（例えば茶道の「～流」に用いられる「派」や「派閥」とは異なる意味）、「勧修寺流」は「Kaju-ji Temple line」に訂正しました。勧修寺流の説明を加え、本姓が藤原である理由、また全体としてどのような人物であったか推測できるようにしました。
sen.e: She was from one of the branch lines of Kaju-ji Temple line (one of the 13 families designated as "meike" (one of the court noble family ranks designated to assume a certain official post in government) branched out from the Takafuji line of the Northern House of Fujiwara clan); her Father was Yorishige UESUGI.
She was a legal wife of Sadauji ASHIKAGA.
She was a legal wife of Sadauji ASHIKAGA.
She was a legal wife of Sadauji ASHIKAGA.

sen.j: 足利尊氏、足利直義兄弟の母。
sen.e: She was a Mother of the bothers Takauji ASHIKAGA and Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA.
She was a mother of the bothers Takauji ASHIKAGA and Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA.
She was a mother of the bothers Takauji ASHIKAGA and Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA.
She was elder to Norifusa UESUGI and younger sister to Nichijo as sisters.
She was the elder sister to Norifusa UESUGI and the younger sister to Nichijo.
She was the elder sister to Norifusa UESUGI and the younger sister to Nichijo.

sen.j: 嘉元3年（1305年）に尊氏を生む。
sen.e: She gave birth to Takauji in 1305.
She gave birth to Takauji in 1305.
She gave birth to Takauji in 1305.

sen.j: この際、紀伊国粉河寺の観音に祈ったことから、後年建武 (日本)3年（1336年）に粉河寺に戸帳を寄付し、さらに翌年には領地を寄進している。
sen.e: For the occasion, she prayed in Kii-Porvince Kokawa Temple and this led her to donate tocho to the temple in 1336 and additionally she donated territory in the following year.

For that occasion, she prayed for kannon (a Bodhisattva with compassion) enshrined at Kokawa-dera Temple in Kii Province; consequently this led her to donate tocho (a woven fabric to cover the shelf to enshrine kannon statue) to the temple in 1336, and she additionally donated her estate to the temple in the following year.
sen.cmt: 「観音」を説明とともに訳出しました。紀伊国粉河寺の訳を用語集に合わせました。「戸帳」の説明を加えました。領地については「territory」を「estate」に修正しました。
sen.e: For that occasion, she prayed for kannon (a Bodhisattva with compassion) enshrined at Kokawa-dera Temple in Kii Province; consequently this led her to donate tocho (a woven fabric to cover the shelf to enshrine kannon statue) to the temple in 1336, and she additionally donated her estate to the temple in the following year.

sen.j: 夫貞氏の没後も足利家を支え、尊氏、直義兄弟が倒幕に動いた際には終始行動をともにした。
sen.e: After the death of her husband Sadauji, she supported the Ashikaga clan and she went along with her sons Takauji and Tadayoshi when they moved to topple the bakufu.
Even after the death of her husband Sadauji, she continued to support the Ashikaga clan; she went along with her sons Takauji and Tadayoshi when they took action to overthrow Kamakura bakufu.
sen.cmt: 「貞氏の生前から没後も」の意味と考え、修正しました。倒幕を「topple the bakufu」としています。単なる勢力者を倒すのではなく「幕府を倒す」という意味ですので、「overthrow」に修正しました。なお、次項目で「室町幕府成立」との説明が続くため、ここでの「倒幕」に対し「鎌倉幕府」と追記しています。
sen.e: Even after the death of her husband Sadauji, she continued to support the Ashikaga clan; she went along with her sons Takauji and Tadayoshi when they took action to overthrow Kamakura bakufu.

sen.j: 室町幕府成立後は、実家である上杉家の興隆に力を用いた。
sen.e: After the Muromachi bakufu was established, she helped to the rise of the Uesugi family.
After the establishment of Muromachi bakufu, she utilized her influence to help prosper her parents house, the Uesugi family.
sen.cmt: 「実家である」の訳を補いました。口語調で説明不足でしたのでわかりやすくなるよう表現を変えました。
sen.e: After the establishment of Muromachi bakufu, she utilized her influence to help prosper her parents house, the Uesugi family.

sen.j: 浄妙院殿雪庭と号し、世上は錦小路殿と呼ばれた。
sen.e: She used the name Jomyoin and was commonly called Nishikikoji also.
She called herself as Jomyo-inden Settei, and was called by the common name Nishikikoji dono.
sen.cmt: 「殿雪庭」を訳出しました（「浄妙院」ではなく、「浄妙」と「院殿」、「雪庭」で構成された名前です）。
sen.e: She called herself as Jomyo-inden Settei, and was called by the common name Nishikikoji dono.

sen.j: 和歌にも通じ、作品が『風雅集』に入選している。
sen.e: She was also versed in waka and her works were selected in "Fugashu".
She was also well versed in Waka (a form of Japanese traditional poetry), and her works were selected in acollection of poems, "Fugashu."
sen.cmt: 和歌の説明を加えました。
sen.e: She was also well versed in Waka (a form of Japanese traditional poetry), and her works were selected in acollection of poems, "Fugashu."

sen.j: 法号は果証院殿といい、墓は京都等持院にある。
sen.e: Her posthumous Buddhist name was Kashoin and her burial ground is located in Kyoto Toujiin Temple.
Her posthumous Buddhist name was Kasho-inden, and her grave is located at Touji-in Temple in Kyoto.
sen.cmt: 「院殿」を訳出しました（「果証」と「院殿」から構成される法号です）。「墓」は"burial ground"とは限らないため（日本では埋葬・火葬は時代により分かれるため）、"grave"に修正しました。「京都等持院」の訳を用語集にあわせて修正しました。
sen.e: Her posthumous Buddhist name was Kasho-inden, and her grave is located at Touji-in Temple in Kyoto.
